p: In the native state, the CoV S protein exists as an inactive precursor. During viral infection, target cell proteases activate the S protein by cleaving it into S1 and S2 subunits [ 17], which is necessary for activating the membrane fusion domain after viral entry into target cells [ 18]. Similar to other coronaviruses, the S protein of SARS-CoV-2 is cleaved into S1 and S2 subunits by cellular proteases, and the serine protease TMPRSS2 is used as a protein primer. Although the cleavage site of SARS-CoV is known, that of SARS-CoV-2 S has not yet been reported [ 18, 19].
